document.title: Indiana Academic Standards Digital Media: Grades 9-12

DD385793BB384CF4934BBB8C37357D0D.description: Analyze case studies or examples and evaluate how ethical responsibilities and principles affect media credibility.

AE0033CB799B41C1B56F9FC405ADDA02.description: Analyze ethical guidelines or codes of ethics and explain how or why they are an integral part of the media industry.

A55E2B449E434ABFA4B8434BA0A404CE.description: Identify essential ethical principles and legal limitations within various platforms of media, including student media.

45824EF98BBC48499416BF0FF91BEFB0.description: Analyze how media law influences the purpose and function of the media industry, including student media.

6AB25AC2D5C348B2BB020343E9492143.description:
Evaluate the rights, the responsibilities, and the role of a free, independent press in a democratic society to maintain
accuracy, balance, fairness, objectivity, and truthfulness.

02B999846117450BB21238CC62B07B86.description:
Students understand and apply knowledge of legal and ethical principles related to the functioning of a free and
independent press and various media platforms in the United States.

33F40984CEBC4B2BB0579770A5E5AC0B.description: Evaluate the credibility of sources in a variety of print and digital media.

48140DF45BF84633A7719AC3B2760D70.description: Compare and contrast coverage of the same stories in a variety of print and digital media.

B4F9372AC324404092F47D46ADABBC8C.description:
Analyze and evaluate how the consumerism of the media industry influences how content is produced, distributed, and
directed toward specific users.

A93D300AC1D946A4A0B1268AE4B7766A.description:
Identify and describe how frequent access and critical analysis of media can enhance the ability of citizens to make
informed choices when exercising democratic freedoms.

50B5DA69FC834B79A9E453E3D2535C09.description: Compare media content choices over a variety of outlets and platforms.

3F8B0F44FC1A4B1BAE954D5FE73160FF.description:
Analyze media industry content choices in relation to their specific audience and identify which possible
points of bias and prejudice exist, and

73104B22D1CE47F59CF28502C7BC4624.description: Increasing awareness of cultural similarities and differences as well as recognize their interdependence,

9CB1AA59EDBE44259A861C9D1EAA3136.description: Analyze and evaluate the role of media in transmitting cultural and shaping public opinion, including:

8767F56397474BB0A1145A3E550D5880.description:
Identify choices producers make while constructing media. Evaluate how choices contribute to the impact on the
audience.

1BFFDA0252C648AEA9C06F38ED156D49.description: Analyze the impact of the media on the public, including identifying rhetorical appeals and logical fallacies.

473B51546A124E7BAD121F71AE503E2B.description:
Evaluate the intersections and conflicts between visual and verbal messages, and recognize how visual techniques or
design elements carry or influence messages in various media.

ADB13DCCD1284317A2BE68D3FC947E31.description: Critically analyze content found in media used to inform, persuade, entertain, and transmit culture.

498A2ABDE56A4F259A888F982E1A812C.description:
Create engaging content that strategically and creatively uses digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and
interactive elements) to add interest and enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence.

728265B88F6D413CA9A523C95F195936.description:
Using a range of informal and formal tasks, present information, findings, and supporting evidence, conveying a clear
and distinct perspective, such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning, opposing perspectives are addressed,
ensuring the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience.

3A842354E95340CC8CCE5D35024D05C2.description:
Evaluate a speaker’s point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links
among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used.

F6DF936AD38D4366AA905EBCE1B9D32A.description:
Integrate multiple sources of information presented in multiple formats (e.g., graphics, photos, illustrations, public
records, audio, video) in order to make informed decisions, solve problems, or create evaluating the credibility,
accuracy, and feasibility noting any discrepancies among the information.

9CE51CDFAA6D4E88B1D720CC4E50ADAD.description:
Conduct debate and discussion to allow all views to be presented; allow for a dissenting view, in addition to group
compromise; and determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the investigation or complete
the task.

99CE2883E5FC4477A7E6169C70070301.description:
Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and evidence; ensure a hearing for a
full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and
creative perspectives.

91ECA447ED584658BC30C4E5B450A964.description:
Work with peers to promote collegial discussions and decision-making, set clear goals and deadlines, and establish
individual roles as needed.

1E9B975430914E8EAD2E7679B8059AAA.description: Engage in a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas by referring to specific evidence.

85C5C613BC7B434AAA1CA28CCEB606A8.description:
Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, critiques, group discussion,
interviews, etc.) on current events, sample media, newsworthy issues, creative story ideas, use of technology in
projects; building on others’ ideas and expressing personal viewpoints and narratives clearly.

DAB1C997E7414B98B262D597CF13AEF6.description:
Listen actively and adjust the use of spoken language (e.g., conventions, style, vocabulary, probing questions) to
communicate effectively with a variety of sources and audiences and for different purposes and media platforms.

210491855A664C7687B93972D9D69329.description: Spelling –Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

5CBDBC1DF81C44A58BAB9B3DF6D74C59.description: Punctuation –Students are expected to buildupon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

AEC4E54BFD714253B30398215C3FCE81.description: Capitalization–Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

DA9DAA3090BD4FDBB150B338A34660A3.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation,
and spelling focusing on:

3709460826214BE4BEA01A9122435AB5.description: Usage- Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

4EE5B41E467E42EB88B583E4C3F123D3.description:
Phrases and Clauses – Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned
previously.

44F1A8B3E2C946C08A6C8C57CD36EC3A.description:
Adjectives and Adverbs – Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned
previously.

50D5CCAEA7B04EBFA1D82AB02B2D3FA1.description: Verbs - Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

F6DD7F68530B4106AE69FEE6DF079339.description: Pronouns– Students are expected to build upon and continue applying conventions learned previously.

93DE4859D7D947CD85690DE4FEC69D8F.description: Demonstrate command of English grammar and usage, focusing on:

8E8256B1AB884653BA4A2B40EC5828D5.description: Conventions of Standard English: Grammar and Usage / Capitalization, Punctuation, and Spelling

B3D835F163A74A90AD4121D50DB0A128.description: Keeping dated notes or interview records on file.

725E710057C74B1B806E045BA82898FC.description: Double-checking information before writing the story, and

0AF0B1719D3346A9B20BDC781CFFF268.description: Observing and recording details during the interview,

CC66D720B5434CFF88F0E0F992EF791E.description: Formulating questions that elicit valuable information,

D450AACE21E8403C8BDBD744A369566D.description: Ask clear interview questions to guide a balanced and unbiased information-gathering process that include:

A79FD21BE2954E00A032C745D04405BD.description: Present information, choosing from a variety of formats.

BB512EE82316496AB4F38A33865B7BDE.description: Avoid plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and follow a standard format (e.g., AP Style) for citation.

8CFDDBE574344BB8AF2CF878338F04EA.description: Synthesize and integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas.

8C030B17BA784175A06E954CF78EDCF4.description: Assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience,

A58E65316E17461A9F180F7FB7BF3ACD.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple types of authoritative sources, using advanced searches effectively, and
annotate sources,

187A3781A5924F6F9A8C4B6906383104.description: Formulate an inquiry question, and refine and narrow the focus as research evolves,

A246FD37FE684CCBBB0FD20FE4BD2622.description:
Conduct short as well as more sustained research assignments and tasks to build knowledge about the research
process and the topic under study:

2AFD9BF71C3B4480AD96FF658F4BE59F.description:
Identify relevant issues and events of interest to readers through current news analysis, surveys, research reports,
statistical data, and interviews with the audience.

453A4E67DA4443CE916D4BE8FEAFA3A3.description: Discuss ideas for writing with classmates, teachers, other writers, or community members.

817A5FDD783540E3A2CBE47219D59645.description: The Research Process: Finding, Assessing, Synthesizing, and Reporting Information

FED0A25E522B4900A883ECE4926C6CCC.description:
Follow ethical standards related to information gathering that include the appropriate citing of sources and the
importance of avoiding plagiarism.

E5A93929E49A40468528C874436E9F4E.description: Revise and edit to ensure effective, grammatically correct communication.

A1D8E017072E445AB53A1C3D326F02DE.description:
Revise and edit to improve sentence variety and style and to enhance subtlety of meaning and tone in ways that are
consistent with purpose, audience, and media format.

B545564225EA41EB96691E3BCDF58982.description: Evaluate and revise the content for meaning, clarity, and purpose.

D133F7B172964DE5AD35AAE00F3ACEC7.description:
Utilize a standard style guide framework for properly crediting sources in all media product types, utilizing multiple
sources when appropriate.

3ECA1036C9E3409C85D8DCBF01EB1C0B.description:
Use technology to generate, produce, publish, and update individual or shared products in response to ongoing
feedback, including new arguments or information,

C1E7768E797C4CC9B5D04440825025A5.description:
Plan and develop, draft, revise using appropriate reference materials, rewrite, try a new approach, focusing on
addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience, and edit to produce and strengthen.
writing that is clear and coherent,

1CD24D3E241C49CDAC798C8E9C6C97E3.description:
Apply the writing process to all formal writing and media product development, including but not limited to
argumentative, informative, and narrative.

45BF157C63C3477F9187BDF00242620B.description:
Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the
experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

42FF4346E9D64358AD58842339BCCAED.description:
Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and
build toward a particular tone and outcome,

8673C490B54842098876A70710DC7633.description:
Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple anecdotes to develop
experiences, events, and/or sources,

39327AD201B44DB6882030FB56871572.description: Create a smooth progression of experiences or events,

8AD16B37F5EB40B18D54A90D25C5162A.description:
Engage and orient the audience by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance,
establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and including narration and/or sources or characters,

D41DB0949C7547C8ADA60CA786D47B6C.description: Write or produce narrative and feature-style media products in a variety of forms that:

FEF7E0C6886442D894D31AF3C65D638C.description:
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation
presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

60A2C343F0F94652AFC2A48ABF410CFE.description: Establish and maintain an informative style appropriate to the purpose and audience, and

88B1649677F84C6880367F85C797E73B.description:
Choose language, content- specific vocabulary, and techniques to manage the complexity of the topic,
recognizing and eliminating wordiness and redundancy,

13FC855715CB4E5A8FAE3EB3BB9CE213.description:
Use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the piece,create cohesion, and
clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts,

91CADC7F498F497BAD81D574248DD8AF.description:
Utilize credible sources, develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts,
extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the
audience’s knowledge of the topic,

EE1A002D87924C428D25CF50E1C90687.description:
Introduce a topic using a variety of lead-ins; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each
new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting(e.g., headings),
graphics (e.g.,figures,tables),and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension,

8C286976C3EB45CFAF65A2F3E5DC16F3.description: Write or produce informative products on a variety of topics that:

47295F58D14E40A49286BE7575651283.description: Maintain a balance between individual events and more general and abstract ideas,

BF03BF9A04A542EF861211C38F0CCA44.description:
Draw comparisons between specific incidents and broader themes related to important beliefs or
generalizations about life,

3916AE143E9F4238A17E5786CEF1F7A8.description: Explore the personal significance of an experience,

12A5A80998E94C9196DCD9677B5BAA94.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented,

0FB722EC2E004D86BACA91891A39E461.description: Establish and maintain a consistent style and tone appropriate to purpose and audience,

90BDA37FF959417F9FA1A0553116011D.description:
Use effective and varied transitions as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the media piece,
create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence,
and between claim(s) and counterclaims,

3749BCC024714CF4BAA88B618609FDC8.description:
Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while
pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience’s knowledge level,
concerns, values, and possible biases,

362968850A1F47DE93DF030CDDE15172.description: Use rhetorical strategies to enhance the effectiveness of the claim,

B4E7174BD2C3415C9780A990720FB411.description:
Introduce precise claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or
opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and
evidence,

DC3E5F9EFFCF4C8F9557CF4971D29EB3.description: Write or produce arguments or commentaries in a variety of forms that:

E419B3AB80EC4DF79E22251D05814A0D.description: Writing Genres: Editorial, News, Feature, and Narrative

63D319180F574FA28F62C5BD5D99B013.description: Write legibly in print or cursive, forming letters and words that can be read by others.

2AF459E3A8E641109DDC9200E74938FF.description:
Write routinely over a variety of time frames for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences; apply reading standards to
support analysis, reflection, and research by drawing evidence from a variety of texts and media products.

0DC2935149394727B703BDD8F12C40B3.description:
Interpret figures of speech and the use of colloquial terms (e.g. paradox and idiom) in context and analyze their role in a
text or media product.

85D40D0E08624B5EA4641C9BBBDE3EA7.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a nonfiction text, including figurative, connotative, and
technical meanings; evaluate the cumulative impact of how an author or producer uses and refines the meaning of a
key term or terms over the course of a text or media product.

23EBA9FC98044BB5889FFACFD51DF7D0.description:
Analyze the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in media products including figurative and connotative
meanings; analyze the cumulative impact of specific word choices (e.g., imagery, allegory, and symbolism) on meaning
and tone (e.g. how the language evokes a sense of time and place; how it sets a formal and informal tone).

8EDA2DC464E3496FAC24BA32895D6BEF.description: Vocabulary in Media Writing and Production

AC384AC6645C4B54BDEF340C8538D491.description:
Identify and apply knowledge of media-related terms in the following areas: media production process (pre-production,
production, post-production), news reporting, writing, law, ethics, and technology.

B53503200E3B40BFA27EEF77CA5E9200.description:
Select appropriate general and specialized reference materials to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or
clarify its precise meaning, part of speech, etymology, or standard usage (e.g. Associated Press Stylebook).

570553A77DAF431FA076987F4DC9CA89.description:
Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., conceive,
conception, conceivable).

437B1946378A4024AB42749CBD6D31A8.description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

158C8BBDB74F4221A763C95C4A727E9A.description: Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words (e.g. synonym/antonym, analogy).

A05B302F2A6043F59A7842353303FBE6.description: Use context to determine or clarify the meaning of words and phrases.

FB93040BCE7F40648DEA75CE0A6833DC.description:
Acquire and accurately use academic and content-specific words and phrases at the college and career readiness
level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to
comprehension or expression, including those standard to the media industry.

E9021F1373EB40008C372463B7C5F98A.description:
Analyze and synthesize foundational U.S. and world documents, such as the First Amendment and relevant case law,
for their themes, purposes and rhetorical features.

37BE73B1354E48988615096E687706BC.description:
Synthesize and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different mediums in order to address a question
or solve a problem.

BD545983A86E426FBB4A4F89A771414B.description:
Delineate and evaluate the arguments and specific claims in U.S.and world media, assessing whether the reasoning is
valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; analyze the impact of false statements and fallacious reasoning (e.g.
misinformation/disinformation, copyright, libel/slander, plagiarism, privacy, First Amendment).

ACAF9F75DA3247BAA5D6E0817998C8D4.description:
Determine perspective or purpose in a piece of media in which the rhetoric is particularly effective. Analyze how style
and content contribute to the power and persuasiveness of the media product (e.g.appeals to both friendly and hostile
audiences and anticipates and addresses audience’s concerns and counterclaims).

F4747B59626F4311BF2342D15EF2FD6E.description:
Analyze and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure used in a persuasive argument including whether the structure
makes points that are clear, convincing, and engaging.

5AAF0B781AEB47D9ADA0072265312C60.description:
Apply knowledge of text features in multiple print and digital sources to locate information, gain meaning from a text, or
solve a problem.

D7DFB8CC8D98400097E426DC40E588A0.description:
Analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific ideas, facts, events, or individuals
develop throughout the product.

1BBEC6D4BB874FE2B8270BD46B381F66.description:
Analyze the development of similar central ideas across two or more media products and determine how specific
details shape and refine the central idea.

9702339C9FDA469695B2B4F187D64CA0.description:
Analyze what a nonfiction media product says explicitly as well as inferences and interpretations drawn from the piece,
including determining where the piece leaves matters uncertain by citing strong and thorough facts from observations,
quotations, and specific details.

6548ADDD91A64CBB8DDB321A2D58E461.description:
Read a variety of nonfiction media from journalistic outlets and read other texts related to media within a range of
complexity appropriate for grades 9-12 that include possibilities for analysis of literary techniques, structure and style.
By the end of this course, students interact with media products and texts proficiently and independently at the low end
of the range and with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

CBFD3C66B52E4FBB9FF5644C7B8262F1.description:
Analyze and evaluate media of historical or cultural significance and how two or more media products treat similar
themes, conflicts, issues, or topics, and maintain relevance for current audiences.

F57836D4FF384BFEA035A5ACFD877098.description:
Analyze multiple interpretations or adaptations of a story and evaluate how each version interprets the original source
and the impact of the interpretations on the audience.

B734E571CD964DF7B877BC25803A9546.description:
Analyze a media product in which the audience must distinguish between what is directly stated and what is intended in
order to understand the perspectives.

6B6C00E73A8B4FB39ED984BE183D1BEE.description:
Analyze and evaluate how a producer’s choices concerning how to structure specific parts of a media product
contribute to its overall meaning and effect.

1C54991BB6D949F6BE11877A0B606349.description:
Make predictions about the context of text using prior knowledge of text features, explaining whether they were
confirmed or not confirmed and why and be able to utilize and continue the skills.

C8C72D39188E40BB960CC31407ADEF2A.description: Analyze how the producer’s choices impact subject development over the course of a media product.

2C976BF2BC184806A9439EB453E5BB1A.description:
Compare and contrast the development of similar themes across two or more media products and analyze how they
emerge and are shaped and refined by specific details.

E3DD5514D5604B1FAAE5589A41EE52F6.description:
Analyze what a product says explicitly and implicitly as well as inferences and interpretations drawn from the media
product through citing evidence determining where the product leaves matters uncertain.

2B7975B654E644F5B93189140098CCCA.description:
Read and interact with a variety of media from journalistic outlets and read other texts related to media within a range of
complexity appropriate for grades 9-12 that include possibilities for analysis of literary techniques, structure and style.
By the end of this course, students interact with media and texts proficiently and independently at the low end of the
range and with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
